div1.p: Your letter was a gift from heaven, but sometimes, I suppose we must struggle to reach the goals such gifts deserve.

The man on whom I had every justification to depend seemed joyously interested in collaborating on the "Song of Hugh Glass" article — has become a sadly changed personality now. Some months ago he gave up a job, planning to earn his living by writing. "Fate" has accepted two of his articles, published in the Feb. cruncher (+ he won a poetry prize (though I feel he exaggerated his abilities as a poet. Shortly after this he sent another article to Fate (in Feb.) they did not pay for it, return it,
20
2
nor given him any comment, so he says he has lost all interest in the magazine. Especially when he subscribed to "Fate," + they omitted sending him an issue one month.

I told him (on the phone) to ask the editor why he had not heard from them. Hope he will. This man writes a surprisingly good letter. He had one poem published "Ajax" by a local poetry magazine, whoich however, does not pay for verse. He devotes himself now to his printing press

I will try to query "Fate" on their interest in the article. I thnk I can get other collaboration, which is necessary for though I deeply look forward to hearing the recording, my diminished sight would make note-taking impossible. Daughter Margaret suggests any good magazine, such as Atlantic or Harpers should be interested in this experience of a historical poet, if the article is well written. What do you think? Your experience gives me lofty fascination. Margaret is overloaded with work, as the secretary to her teacher husband and good wife (attending many meetings, working the garden, her activities
4
with the "League of Women Voters," radio + television appearances. She keeps no maid, + is also a good daughter, reading to me the letters I receive. Typing my important letters that I may make corrections, + then write them over. (it is usually impossible for me to read my own caligraphy or any other.)

So with all these obstacles I still have eagerness for this remarkable experience in poetry, + will feel frustrated if I negate your faith in me. (I wonder do you know of any other instance in which a poet divined the locale with the 'inner eye'?)
Do not impose upon yourself a long letter, dear friend, only write if you feel you wish to give some advice.

You will realize that my quasi-literary activities are not of vanity but (also) something in retribution in my life for which I am not completely irresponsible. Were Gustave with me, how different everything would be!
Blessings on you, + those dear to you. It gives me more faith in life when I see another place so brave + achieving her significant desires.
Always with more courage because of you

postscript.p: Please condone possible repetition — Did not wish to delay this letter longer, + Margaret was called away
So glad you let me come to your "Sweet Home" — also that I saw some of your interesting work — dear + your precious grandchildren Good greetings to the family also from Margaret.
